key_behaviors: Uses AI tools (Google Gemini, ChatGPT) on a weekly basis for personal tasks
Uploads class objectives or PowerPoint slides to generate practice exam questions
Uses AI as an editor for grammar and style improvements in papers
Prefers web‑based AI over installed software (e.g., Grammarly) because it runs cooler on the laptop
Employs AI for brainstorming ideas despite occasional hallucinations
Cross‑checks AI‑generated content against personal notes to verify accuracy
Envisions AI assisting with meal planning, grocery shopping, budgeting, and calendar/email management
pain_points: AI sometimes provides false or fabricated information (hallucinations) that is hard to detect
Time wasted verifying inaccurate AI output, especially when searching for non‑existent studies
Grammarly overheats the computer, making the web AI feel more convenient
Lack of seamless integration with personal systems (calendar, email) limits usefulness
AI appears to recognize buzzwords without true understanding, leading to shallow conversations
trust_factors: Higher trust when AI output can be validated against personal notes or known sources
Trust increased by convenience and performance (web AI runs smoother than installed tools)
Trust decreased by hallucinations and inability to verify information automatically
desires: AI that can generate meal‑prep ideas using the same set of ingredients to save time and money
Budgeting assistance that incorporates local cost data and personal financial experience
Deep integration with calendar and email to auto‑populate events, summarize messages, and organize spam
A more human‑like conversational ability: asking clarifying questions, providing contextual anecdotes, and showing genuine understanding
Reliable fact‑checking or source citation to reduce hallucinations

verbatim_quotes.quote: Google Gemini, ChatGPT
Weekly

I use AI to ask for practice questions. I either upload the objectives given to me by school or the PowerPoint, depending on what I'm using, and ask for a few test questions based on my profession and our board certification.

I really enjoy that online, there's a lot of different information on my certification exam. I like that AI can use that information from the Internet and then create questions based on the material I'm learning.
It helps generate questions that I might not have thought of, written in a style similar to my professors or board writers.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Benefit of AI mimicking professor style

verbatim_quotes.quote: I have used AI and Grammarly. ... Grammarly has overheated my computer, so it's more of a convenience thing.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Preference for web AI over installed editor

verbatim_quotes.quote: It seems like my computer is doing better on this website instead of software that's downloaded onto my laptop.
There have been instances where I'll be asking it prompts, like brainstorming ideas, and it will provide me with information that isn't necessarily true.
It's hard to tell when it's giving me false information. Sometimes I might catch it, but maybe other times I don't realize it's providing false information.
If it gives me a study that didn't actually happen and I'm trying to find those results online, it's more difficult to locate them because they don't exist.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Impact of false information on productivity

verbatim_quotes.quote: I think that it has led me to use AI for things like creating questions where I can refer to my own notes and know what's correct and what's incorrect, rather than letting it provide information and believing it at face value.
3 - Moderate trust
For day-to-day life, I feel like it would be nice if AI could create meal prep ideas for me, based on the same ingredients, so that whenever I'm grocery shopping, I could shop efficiently.
Maybe budgeting assistance would also be nice.

As a student right now, my program does not allow us to have a job because it is so rigorous. So, with AI helping me to meal plan and suggest a few different meals that use the same ingredients, it would help me be cost‑effective by knowing what I need.

I think that creating a sustainable budget would be really useful. It might provide more insight on the average cost of things, especially in my area, or what might be realistic based on what has worked for other people.
Maybe it could take things from my calendar or my email and add them to my calendar automatically. Perhaps it can summarize different emails or be more efficient with where my emails are going.
I think that being interviewed by AI was a lot more intelligent than I was expecting. There was a lot of feedback based on what I was saying. However, I think I prefer human interaction more.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Preference for human vs. AI interaction

verbatim_quotes.quote: The AI seems to pick up on buzzwords but doesn't fully grasp what I'm saying.
There's no way for me to 100% tell that it understood the message I was saying, whereas a human might be able to ask for clarification and go more in‑depth...
You just miss those small, minuscule conversations that connect humans together.

unique_insights: The participant leverages AI not only as a study aid but as a surrogate exam‑writer, uploading course materials to generate board‑style questions that mimic professor phrasing—a use case that blends content creation with personalized learning. They switched from a dedicated editing app to a web AI primarily for performance reasons (overheating), highlighting hardware constraints as a driver of tool adoption. Their ideal assistant spans academic, culinary, and financial domains and explicitly calls for tight integration with personal data streams (calendar, email) while also demanding human‑like conversational depth and reliable fact‑checking, revealing a desire for a unified life‑manager rather than a set of siloed utilities.
